alert.note: Alert for Greenwood; Newberry; Saluda (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 8:56PM EST until January 13 at 7:19AM EST by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Wateree River Near Camden affecting Kershaw County. Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Calhoun, Richland and Lexington Counties. Pee Dee River At Cheraw affecting Chesterfield and Marlboro Counties. Enoree River At Whitmire affecting Newberry and Union Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Congaree River At Columbia affecting Richland and Lexington Counties. Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Calhoun and Richland Counties. Saluda River At Chappells affecting Newberry, Greenwood and Saluda Counties. Wateree River At Lake Wateree affecting Fairfield, Kershaw and Lancaster Counties. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Saluda River at Chappells. * WHEN...Until Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Lowlands around and downstream from Chappells become flooded. Cattle grazing river bottomland should be moved to higher ground. At 16.0 feet, Extensive farmland and river bottomland around and downstream from Chappells become flooded. At 18.0 feet, The Saluda River Campground including the Campground Store downstream from Chappells becomes flooded. Campers should move to higher ground. At 21.0 feet, Extensive flooding occurs. Farmland and river bottomland around and downstream from Chappells become flooded. Much of the Saluda River Campground downstream from Chappells become flooded. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EST Wednesday the stage was 20.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 20.5 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage Friday morning to 6.9 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor rising water levels and take action if necessary. Most flooding deaths occur in vehicles. Never drive through a flooded roadway or around barricades. Turn around, don`t drown. Flooded roadways are nearly impossible to see at night. Avoid traveling in this area. Turn around, don`t drown. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. Thursday morning at 900 AM EST.
